# Arpeggio: Major 7th in D# (Shape: G)

## Brief Presentation
An arpeggio is the technique of playing individual notes of a chord in a sequential order rather than simultaneously. The major 7th arpeggio in D# (enharmonically equal to Eb) using the G shape refers to playing the notes of a D# major 7th chord starting from the note G. 

## Notes and Intervals
- The notes of a D# major 7th chord are D# (root), F## (major 3rd), A# (perfect 5th), and C## (major 7th).
- Using the G shape to play this arpeggio, the notes played in sequence would be G (root), A# (perfect 5th), C## (major 7th), and D# (root again).

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The major 7th arpeggio in D# using the G shape is commonly found in jazz, R&B, and soul music. It adds a sophisticated and jazzy flavor to the sound, often used to create smooth, dreamy, and emotive passages in music.

## Songs
1. **"Autumn Leaves" by Joseph Kosma** - This jazz standard features the major 7th arpeggio in various keys, showcasing its elegance and melancholic vibe.
2. **"Don't You Worry 'Bout a Thing" by Stevie Wonder** - The major 7th arpeggio in D# can be heard in the keyboard part of this R&B classic, adding a touch of soulful sophistication.
3. **"All of Me" by John Legend** - This contemporary R&B hit incorporates the major 7th arpeggio, particularly in the piano accompaniment, contributing to its soulful and heartfelt sound.
